text:
Hello,
Have you tried changing 'Content-Type' to 'application/json' in your headers?

Do both
```{% image "image" %}```
and
```{% image_src "image_src" %}```
resize + webp images? Any other variation or setup that works?

got it thanks. then that will be the solution for clients not having hubDB option within their budget

thanks !

Image resizing happens based on `height` and `width` attributes being set or the developer choosing to use `resize_image_url`.

Some Image best practices are listed here: <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/guides/speed#images>

additionally you can lazy load your images for even greater performance:
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/guides/speed/lazy-loading>
(it’s mentioned on the performance doc as well)
Thanks <@U7SL518D6> The resize_image_url function is new to me. Very cool
For more speed tips and tricks, we recently did a developer podcast episode on this <https://youtu.be/9nyAKPYlzhQ>
<@U24GZQ3GF> what does your JSON look like, and what call are you making?
Watching these in reverse order, listening to episode 5 now

Nice!

Thankfully aside from us on the HubSpot side getting better and better at doing them the content can easily be listened to in any order.
This latest episode is really hitting on a lot of good points / questions—the marketer + developer experience is really a unique dynamic when building in HubSpot
Lately I've been trying to balance getting more familiar with new tech and getting more familiar with all the new stuff HubSpot is launching

It can be a hard thing to keep up with tech including HubSpot. It’s impossible to digest all of the changes happening all at once, too much change is happening too quickly. So my suggestion is focus on what will drive results or efficiency for you in the shorter term. While still consuming a little bit of that bigger picture and industry wide cutting edge information even if it doesn’t yet make sense to you.

Somewhere in there is a good balance to where you can get things done, produce results for customers, make money, while also ensuring you’ve got a bright career ahead.
Hi, has anybody tried getting the content of a module by using ajax request and passing it on the current web page?
Oh this is just the "Developer Info" link from the Sprocket Menu
